Column Comment.0: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.1: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.2: COMPOSITE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is acomposite.
Column Comment.3: DRILLING MUD INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is adrilling mud.
Column Comment.4: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.5: ELEMENT INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is anelement.
Column Comment.6: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.7: HYDROCARBON INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance isa hydrocarbon.
Column Comment.8: ION INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is an ion.
Column Comment.9: ISOMER INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is anisomer.
Column Comment.10: ISOTOPE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is anisotope.
Column Comment.11: MINERAL INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is amineral.
Column Comment.12: ORGANIC MATTER INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substanceis organic matter.
Column Comment.13: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.14: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance ispreferred.
Column Comment.15: PREFERRED LONG NAME: the usual or preferred name given to this substancebehavior.
Column Comment.16: PREFERRED SHORT NAME: Common short name used for the production entity.
Column Comment.17: PRODUCTION STUFF INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not thissubstance is production stuff.
Column Comment.18: TABLE PROPERTY CONTROL SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the propertycontrol information. This can be used to help you control how a vertical table isimplemented, by determining preferred units of measure, data entry types and otherspecifications for each kind of property that is defined.
Column Comment.19: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data
Column Comment.20: SOLVENT INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance is asolvent.
Column Comment.21: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.22: SOURCE DOCUMENT: The literature reference for the information about thesubstance in this row.
Column Comment.23: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.ho lastchanged the row.
Column Comment.25: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.27: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
